descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Shawn Marion and Tony Delk scored 21 points apiece to lead a balanced attack as the Suns routed the Kings, 114-88, for their fifth straight home victory.
article.headline: For a change, Suns keep their lead vs. Kings

images.name: Chirstie, Doug 011212 inline
images.caption: Doug Chirstie and the Kings were all tied up against the Suns.

article.linkText: For a change, Suns keep their cool, blow out Kings
article.story:
PHOENIX (AP) -- Shawn Marion took it personally when the Phoenix Suns began blowing leads against Sacramento. Marion and his teammates made up for a summer of frustrating memories on Wednesday night, beating the Kings 114-88 -- a season high for Phoenix and the Kings' second-worst scoring effort. "It was a personal challenge to me," said Marion, who had 21 points and 13 rebounds. "They came in here and beat us last year, and I didn't like that. Everybody didn't like that, because we were up 28 at halftime and they came back and beat us by 11. That's not good." The Kings made up the 28-point deficit last March 7 and beat the Suns 100-89, recording their biggest comeback since the franchise began playing in Sacramento in 1985. Less than two months later, the Kings made up 17- and 19-point deficits in Phoenix while winning Games 3 and 4 of their first-round playoff series, which Sacramento won 3-1. "This team has been rolling, and now they have Chris Webber back," Phoenix's Penny Hardaway said. "We knew they were going to come in and want to win this one. This was a big game for them, also." Tony Delk had 21 points, and John Wallace 19 points and nine rebounds off the bench for the Suns. Hardaway scored 19, and Stephon Marbury had 15 points and 12 assists as the Suns won their fifth consecutive home game. Webber had 21 points and a season-high 12 rebounds, recording his first double-double in three games back from a sprained ankle that sidelined him for the first 20 games of the season. But he and Mike Bibby, who had 15 points, couldn't keep the Kings' four-game winning streak going. The Suns got their fast break going early and outrebounded the NBA's best-rebounding team, 57-39, in what coach Scott Skiles thought was Phoenix's best full-game effort. "That was very impressive. It was clear we had all the answers," Skiles said. The Kings, who trailed by 24 in the second quarter and 61-39 at halftime, made an early run in the third. Webber had two baskets early and capped the 17-7 surge by dunking after an offensive rebound as the Kings closed within 68-56 at the 6:06 mark. But Delk broke the momentum with a 3-pointer, starting a 9-0 spurt in the next two minutes and Sacramento never got closer than 18 the rest of the way. "We had a chance there," Kings coach Rick Adelman said. "We cut it down to 12 or 13, and they hit a 3 right away and then another basket. You know, if you're making a run like that, you've got to sustain it." The Kings missed 11 of their first 13 shots and committed six of their 20 turnovers in the first eight minutes, allowing Phoenix to take a 20-4 lead on a layup by Hardaway with 3:47 remaining in the first quarter. Sacramento only had three turnovers in the second, but the Suns picked up momentum. Delk had a pair of baseline jumpers and a three-point play during a 14-4 run that gave the Suns a 41-20 lead 5:15 into the second quarter, and Marbury opened a 61-37 lead when he made a 3-pointer with 34 seconds left. "I'd like to say it was one of those nights, but I don't think it was," Webber said. "They came out and played hard, and we didn't give ourselves a chance."

Game notes
The Suns have had at least one 20-point scorer in every game. ... The Kings' 14 points in the first quarter matched their season low for a quarter. ... Bibby hadn't had a turnover in more than three games until he threw a bad pass 6:19 in. ... The Kings (17-6) are still tied with last season's team for the best start in franchise history.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
